content: The 21st Century Water Commission is established. The 21st Century Water Commission is established to conduct water studies, assess future water supply needs, project flood risk, water availability, and water quality trends. They will also study current water management programs at various levels. The 21st Century Water Commission is tasked with developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that includes incentives for ensuring a reliable water supply for the next 50 years, utilizing technologies to optimize water quality and availability, and proposing financing options for watershed management plans. The 21st Century Water Commission is developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy, including watershed management plans, regional planning, and promoting nonstructural elements like green infrastructure for stormwater management. It also encourages integrating flood control and water supply projects to capture excess water for conservation and reuse. The 21st Century Water Commission is developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that includes promoting green infrastructure for stormwater management, minimizing impervious surfaces, and restoring natural systems to avoid adverse impacts. The 21st Century Water Commission is developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that evaluates existing hazard mitigation strategies and contingency planning for water management programs in light of climate change impacts. This includes considering the impacts of climate change and incorporating best available climate science in projections for future flood and drought scenarios. The 21st Century Water Commission is developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that evaluates hazard mitigation strategies and contingency planning for water management programs in light of climate change impacts. This includes incorporating climate science in projections for future flood and drought scenarios and identifying adaptation techniques for responding to climate change impacts. Policy considerations include respecting the primary role of States in water rights and uses, ensuring consistency with existing laws and treaties, and identifying duplication among Federal governmental actions. The 21st Century Water Commission is tasked with developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy, evaluating hazard mitigation and contingency planning for water management programs in light of climate change impacts. The Commission aims to identify duplication among Federal governmental programs and improve coordination among Federal, interstate, State, and local agencies, while avoiding suggesting strategies for increased mandates on State and local governments. The Commission is composed of 11 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The 21st Century Water Commission is composed of 11 members appointed by the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, the Committee on Natural Resources, the majority leader of the Senate, the Committee on Environment and Public Works, the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, and the minority leader of the Senate. The 21st Century Water Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various government officials. One member is appointed by the minority leader of the House of Representatives from nominees of the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Natural Resources. Another member is appointed by the minority leader of the Senate from nominees of the Committee on Environment and Public Works. The 21st Century Water Commission consists of 11 members appointed by government officials. Members must have recognized standing in water policy issues and cannot hold other US government positions while serving. The 21st Century Water Commission consists of 11 members appointed by government officials, representing diverse regional perspectives. The Chairperson is elected by majority vote, members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as original appointments, and members receive travel expenses but no compensation. The 21st Century Water Commission members receive travel expenses and per diem. The Commission must hold meetings within 60 days of all original members' appointment and a majority constitutes a quorum. The Chairperson can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Executive Director of the Commission will be compensated at a rate not exceeding the GS-15 pay scale. The employment and termination of the Executive Director require confirmation by a majority of Commission members. The Commission is required to hold a minimum of 10 hearings, which may be held in conjunction with meetings. Hearings allow for testimony and evidence gathering, with at least one hearing in Washington, D.C. for federal agency representatives. The Commission is required to hold a minimum of 10 hearings in distinct geographical regions of the United States, focusing on water resource issues related to climate change. Testimony from individuals with diverse experiences is sought, including those from government and the private sector. Federal agencies must provide information and support upon request. The Commission must provide necessary information and personnel to carry out its duties. Interim reports detailing progress must be submitted annually to the President and Congress. A final report must be submitted within 5 years of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will submit a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and specific Congressional committees. The Commission will terminate within 30 days of submitting the final report. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. $12,000,000 is authorized for carrying out this section. The Commission appropriated $12,000,000 for carrying out this section.
